author: _alterx
content: Hello, my name is Gianni (aka AlterX), I am a senior software developer in C, C++ also .net platform and Qt. I have been working in the IT in general (also strong knowledge on networking and sys admin) for more than 25 years. I am quite expert on real-time middle-ware and back-end (native sockets and threads) on cross-platform. I am also quite new to blockchains, I have a general overview on how they work, I have successfully built-up an in house cardano nodes on raspberry p4 and set up all procedures for back-ups and so on (e.g. I successfully updated new versions of the node + the latest Alonzo hard fork). I have explored smart contract on ethereum, I liked them, but for me they are too high level programming so I lost interest on those (although I would once like to really use them to implement something useful). I am trying to get in to the blockchain world and one day I would like to have it as a full-time job.

author: pipermerriam
content: Good to see all of you here.  Thank you for the introductions.  We are still processing applications.  Ask questions if you have them

author: tsuigeo
content: Wow lots of applications for limited spots! Ive got a question about how you mentioned everything will actually be out in the open and even those not in the program officially may participate. For those of us who want to look into using this opportunity as a springboard to a career in blockchain how kosher would it be to list this as an experience on cvs, portfolios, etc if we participate even if not selected officially? And possibly if there may be any support if it comes to listing references to employers etc?

author: pipermerriam
content:
Good questions.  So "selection" is only about funding.  Those that are selected will be offered a stipend for the duration of the program.  Selection has no bearing on being able to participate in the program.

The program is open and is almost entirely self directed.  There is no curriculum.  No active "teaching".  Anyone may choose to participate independent of being selected for funding if your situation allows.

author: pipermerriam
content: As for using this as a "springboard" into a blockchain career that is entirely up to you.  The program isn't intended or even very well suited for learning how to make blockchain applications.  If "application" development is what you are interested in, there are more effective ways to learn that stuff.  CDAP is about the low level protocol.

author: celestial_cheetah_53805
content:
Its Good To Know That Anybody Can Participate in CDAP.


Welcome Guys Lets Contribute To Ethereum.

Everybody Will Earn Directly or Indirectly from Ethereum.


have Faith and Keep Contributing.


And Anybody Have Some Good Learning materials (or How to Start Contributing Stuff) Keep Sharing It For Newer Members.

author: pipermerriam
content:
Good places to start are the `./notes` from the first cohort.  They contain lots of links to good reading material.  Feel free to make your own `./notes` document in the `cohort-one` repo if you find anything new or if you just want to aggregate the things that were valuable to you: https://github.com/ethereum-cdap/cohort-zero

And the development updates from the first cohort likely contain some good information about the kind of work that is currently being done: https://github.com/ethereum-cdap/cohort-zero/blob/main/development-updates.md

author: celestial_cheetah_53805
content: Thanks For Sharing The Links Sir

author: pipermerriam
content:
There will also be two standup meetings in the next day:

- East Standup Call in 13 hours 40 minutes: https://www.worldtimebuddy.com/?qm=1&lid=2643743,7,100&h=7&date=2021-9-15&sln=21.5-22&hf=1
- West Standup Call in 25 hours 40 minutes: https://www.worldtimebuddy.com/?qm=1&lid=2643743,7,100&h=7&date=2021-9-16&sln=9.5-10&hf=1

author: pipermerriam
content: BTW, the "open secret" for CDAP is that if you show up, engage with the process, do the work, and that work is good, then I will go to great lengths to help you find a way to continue in a sustainable manner.

author: .a37
content:
Hi everyone - Appreciate the initiative to put this program together, I think it's going to create lots of opportunity in this space.

I wanted to ask if NFT smart contracts are a good way to get started in the ETH/SOL space. It's what I'm currently going through to get a handle on everything, but I don't know if it's an edge case of most smart contract applications.

author: dtb_
content: this space is more about the lower level protocol design -- here are some resources from the CDAP github page: https://github.com/ethereum-cdap/cohort-one/blob/master/stage-0-getting-started.md

author: .a37
content: Thank you!
